Articles.Content:
Looking through the past few pages of suggestions, I didn't see anything pertaining to this, so here goes:

Sun:

  • Poles
  • Sunspots
  • Granular features (This is the bit of the surface that is normal)

Moho:

  • Craters (There are about five individual craters that can have their own biomes)
  • Midlands/Highlands/Midland Craters/Highland Craters (Just like the Mun)
  • Polar Lowlands (Basically south pole)
  • Polar Highlands (Basically north pole)
  • Mo-hole (Being especially unusual, this could have its own biome)

Eve:

  • Northern Lowlands
  • Southern Lowlands
  • Highlands
  • Mountains
  • Oceans (Possibly name the big oceans like the craters of the Mun)
  • Craters (There are about 13 large-ish craters)

Gilly:

  • Highlands
  • Lowlands
  • Slopes

Kerbin:

  • Possible inclusion of the large crater as its own biome

Minmus:

  • Bright Highlands
  • Dark Highlands
  • Frozen Oceans (There are about four for individual naming like the Mun's big craters)

Duna:

  • Poles
  • Craters
  • Canyons
  • Mountains
  • Midlands
  • Highlands

Ike:

  • Bright terrain
  • Dark Terrain
  • Poles

Dres:

  • Icy Highlands
  • Rocky Lowlands
  • Lowland Craters
  • Canyon(s)
  • Flatlands

Jool:

  • Equatorial Belt
  • Temperate Belt
  • Polar Zone

Laythe:

  • Ice Caps
  • Shores
  • Oceans
  • Mountains
  • Lowlands

Vall:

  • Lowlands
  • Highlands
  • Ridges
  • Poles

Tylo:

  • Craters (About five major ones)
  • Mares ('seas' at about 1m altitude)
  • Equatorial Lowlands
  • Equatorial Highlands
  • Poles

Bop:

  • Lowlands
  • Highlands
  • Slopes

Pol:

  • Lowlands
  • Highlands
  • Poles
  • Slopes

Eeloo:

  • Ice Sheets
  • Icy Highlands
  • Rocky Lowlands
  • Rocky Cracks
  • Poles
  • Craters (About two)

So, these are the possible biomes that could be added for each world. Most of these will have been thought of anyway, but a few might not have been (like the sunspots).
Nicely done! For the sunspot biome, we could have cooler temperature read outs for the thermometer.
